awd_titl_txt: Shock Wave Studies of Liquids in Earth's Core and Mantle
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support a three-year effort in the Caltech shock wave laboratory to measure properties of rocky and metallic liquids under conditions matching those in the deepest parts of the Earth. This information is critical to interpreting geophysical observations of the lower mantle and core in terms of composition, temperature, heat flow, and evolution over time. It also allows speculative ideas about an early molten earth to be developed into detailed theories. Shock compression is the only experimental method that can simultaneously measure density, pressure, temperature, energy, and sound speed of liquids at such extreme conditions.

The experimental and science agenda in this proposal is driven by key technical advances. Development of an encapsulation technique allowing us to pre-heat silicate glasses well above their melting point without formation of bubbles and in sealed behind a transparent window allows us to observe thermal radiation from the shocked liquid. Measurement of temperatures and sound speeds in shocked magmas will complete our ability to describe their properties at any desired pressure and temperature. Likewise, the development of graded density impactors for customized shock-and-ramp loading paths, together with our pre-heating capability and development of advanced window materials enabled measurement of the sound speeds and densities of liquid iron alloys along actual outer core temperature profiles. This novel experimental measurement will make the well-defined observed gradient in sound speed with depth in the outer core a new and critical constraint on outer core composition.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
This award funded five years of research effort in the Lindhurst Laboratory of Experimental Geophysics at Caltech, aimed at determining the physical properties of minerals, rocks, and magma under the deep Earth conditions. Specifically, the goals include predicting how a very hot early magma ocean would cool and crystallize to the mostly solid planet we have today, whether there are any molten pockets left today, and what their geophysical signatures would be. We chose representative mineral and glass compositions and impacted them with fast-moving projectiles to generate shock waves. We used sensitive high-speed instruments to observe the shock wave speed, the brightness and color of radiated light, and the speed of release waves. These measurements determine the pressure, density, energy, temperature, and sound speed in the shocked material and that, in turn, allows us to construct models of the relations between these variables under any conditions that may occur in the Earth. A second type of related experiment involves recovering material after an impact to study preserved evidence of transformations it experienced under shock, in order to understand similar features in meteorites and impact craters or to synthesize new materials.

The budget for this award explicitly included funds for only 24 experiments but in the end, the science projects enabled by this award include data from about 100 experiments on three gun facilities.

The first achievement of this work was to design a way to shock a silicate liquid (a magma) and observe light radiating from the shocked sample (previous experiments in sealed metal capsules had no view inside). The trick is to heat a glass sample to a certain temperature range where it becomes thermodynamically a supercooled liquid rather than strictly a glass, but it has not yet become soft enough to flow out of the open sample chamber. This removed the need to seal a window against the liquid. We then used this design to measure the radiative shock temperature in a representative magma composition. All previous shock temperature measurements of this type used cold glass or crystal starting materials, which makes it hard to interpret them as directly. The resulting temperatures are lower than would be predicted by simple models that neglect possible changes in heat capacity of magma at high pressure, implying that the heat capacity increases upon compression and constraining how much it increases. This is essential information for linking the heat lost from a cooling magma ocean to the rate of temperature decrease and the time when it begins to crystallize.

A related measurement using the same target but a thinner projectile allowed us to observe the arrival of release waves, which gives a measurement of the sound speed in the shocked liquid. This is highly prized information, very hard to obtain at such extreme temperature and pressure. It both enables better interpretation of the wave speeds measured by seismologists in the deep Earth and a refined model of the temperature gradient in the magma ocean. We also use this experiment as a primary standard for tuning the parameters of the molecular dynamics models described below.

We made substantial progress on designing and executing experiments to make a similar sound speed measurement in metallic liquids that are candidate compositions for the Earth's outer core. Of course, metallic liquids are opaque so a different approach is needed. Our experiments are the first to use graded density impactors (metal plates with smooth changes in composition and hence density) to drive controlled ramps up or down in pressure through a shocked liquid metal. We expect in the near future to be able to use this design to place new constraints on the composition, temperature, and possibler layering of the Earth's core.

We obtained surprising results in recovery experiments aimed at understanding the unique quasicrystalline minerals found in the Khatyrka Meteorite from Russia. This is only known natural occurrence of icosahedral and decagonal quasicrystals, unusual metal alloys otherwise only known from laboratory synthesis. We unambiguously and reproducibly showed that shock waves passing across the interface between Al-rich and Fe-rich or Ni-rich alloys do indeed result in nucleation and growth of quasicrystals. suggesting that the natural examples were also formed by shocks during collisions in the asteroid belt.

Towards the end of the award we began a campaign of atomistic simulations of the same molten materials studied experimentally. The simulations allow insight at a level of detail that cannot be obtained experimentally, and facilitate interpolation among experiments and a systematic view. We use both empirical force-field molecular dynamics, which must be tuned to match experiments, and ab initio molecular dynamics, which uses quantum mechanical principles and requires no experimental input (but is computationally expensive and limited to fewer atoms and shorter simulation times). These led to a new, more accurate way to fit the experimental data.
